name: The CTO Onboarding Process
author: Lewis Adams-Dunstan
publisher: Preparing the Un-Prepared - A Data-Driven Podcast
summary:
I have to say, this was one of the most interesting conversations that I've had on Preparing the Un-Prepared - A Data-Driven Podcast

Thank you Kevin Goldsmith at Anaconda, Inc. for giving me this opportunity to have you on the show.

What's crazy is that when the camera stopped rolling, me and Kevin continued chatting for another 30 minutes behind the scenes and there were so many good things that were missed in the recording. Maybe next time we'll have to book a 2-hour slot haha

Anyway, the most interesting takeaway for me was when Kevin explained about how a start-up of 5 people might not benefit from having a CTO with 25 years of experience whos managed teams of 100+ people. There's seemingly a huge amount of diversity in skill sets from one CTO to another and the job function changes wildly depending on the size of the company, headcount, the business needs etc.

name: Making Distributed Organizations More Effective

summary: An autonomous team model with teams organized around geographical or time-zone proximity can make a distributed organization more effective. With the Reverse Conway Maneuver you can deliberately add or remove bottlenecks to better support the designs you are trying to build.

name: The Tech Leaders Podcast
author: Gareth Davies
summary: Gareth Interviews Kevin Goldsmith, CTO of London based, identity verification provider Onfido. An engineer by trade, Kevin cut his teeth at Microsoft in the 1990's, and was a member of the Windows Media, Windows CE, and Microsoft Research teams at a time when they were scaling into the global behemoth they are today. He was also the Director of Engineering at Adobe Systems for nine years through a similar growth trajectory and also the VP of Engineering, at Spotify where he led, both product development and streaming delivery during a crucial time. We cover the above along with his thoughts on quantum computing, technology innovation and keeping engineering teams motivated during a lockdown.

name: Kevin Goldsmith on the Spotify model and rolling out progression at scale
author: Jonny Burch
summary:
As makers, we're great at designing and building products and experiences that people love. But one thing that we still can't do effectively is design our own careers.

With the help of regular contributors and special guests, I dig into why that is, tackling questions around managing vs making, missing manager tools, soft and hard skills and training, compensation and navigating a new job that's right for you.

We want to help managers to build more satisfying careers for their teams, and designers and makers everywhere to do work they truly love.

name: Kevin Goldsmith on Architecture and Organizational Design
author: Travis Kimmel
summary: Travis Kimmel talks with Kevin Goldsmith about the correspondence between organizational design and software architecture. Their conversation covers: what Conway’s Law is; Kevin’s experiences in different organizational structures (e.g., Avvo, Spotify, Adobe, and Microsoft) and how those structures influenced the software architecture; what the “Reverse Conway Maneuver” is and how organizations can leverage it; how organizations can evolve existing architectures.

name: Tech Leaders Q&A: Kevin Goldsmith, former VP of Engineering at Spotify and former Director of Engineering at Adobe, discusses the future of technology and engineering…
author: Francesca Greane
summary:
In Third Republic’s Tech Leaders Q&A series we speak with industry leaders to hear their thoughts on the ever-evolving technology landscape, and the resulting drive towards digital transformation that we are seeing affect almost every business in every industry.
We recently spoke with Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at Avvo and former Vice President of Engineering at Spotify. Prior to this, Kevin also worked at Adobe and Microsoft. Drawing on his experience from these businesses Kevin shared some of his past success and challenges, as well as his thoughts on how technology and engineering are impacting digital transformation efforts, where he believes the future of digital lies.

name: Microservices at Spotify
author: Ben Linders
summary: Spotify has been doing microservices for quite some years at large scale. Kevin Goldsmith, Vice President of Engineering at Spotify, talked about how Spotify uses microservices to break down architectures and be innovative at the GOTO Berlin 2015 conference. He argues that Microservices are easier to test, deploy and monitor than monolithic applications. Spotify also aims to have as few as possible dependencies in their product, and microservices are very helpful for that.

name: What's it like to work at Spotify?
author: Emma Tracey
summary: According to Kevin Goldsmith, VP of Engineering at Spotify, the Swedish music-streaming mammoth’s success all comes down to its team culture. We sat down with the Carnegie-Mellon educated, Chicago-native at MobiConf Krakow. Over a weak coffee and prior to a strong vodka, he told us all about the fine balance between autonomy and chaos, preserving start-up culture in a large organizations, his escape from Microsoft and why failure is all part and parcel of the life of a continuous improvement organization.

name: Microsoft: Enclave Of Nerds, Or Artists?
summary:
The northwest corner of the United States is home to an arts colony of astounding vigor. The locals paint, draw, sculpt, create sonic art and even have their own orchestra, with rehearsals every Monday and concerts every season.
Is this cradle of creativity centered in Seattle? Portland?
Try Microsoft.
